some of us treat linkedin like a networking event while others treat it like a game of hide and seek.
not sharing your personal and professional journey on LinkedIn is akin to some of these hiding spots, like hiding in a secret door or even a hidden underground garage.
i see so many brilliant entrepreneurs playing the world's greatest game of hide and seek with their audience.
now more than ever, people care more about you and your story than your fancy tech stack and your brand's mission statement.
i've talked with hundreds of founders who finally stopped hiding and embraced building in public. the ones who share their journey through consistent linkedin posts and newsletters are connecting with customers, users, and investors at 10x the speed.
the best founders aren't hiding in walls, they're standing on them, waving their arms, and saying "hey, this is what we're building!". they are getting dms and email replies weekly that lead to real quantifiable opportunities and revenue.
i'm looking to help one founder come out of hiding with some linkedin + newsletter magic. know someone who needs this? tag them below and letâ€™s stop playing hide and seek.
p.s. for those ready to stop hiding, the linkedin hunger games (50 day posting challenge with a twist) has 35+ participants and nearly $2000 in the pot. slide into my dms to join the party.

sometimes our most firmly held beliefs get flipped upside down.
i just watched a turtle break the sound barrier to obliterate a crab in 0.1 second flat.
my entire childhood was a lie. turtles aren't slow â€“ they're strategic assassins playing the long game.
this got me thinking about another "common wisdom" myth we've all heard: email is dying in the social media era.
plot twist: email is thriving more than ever.
be honest with me... how many times have you checked your inbox today? how many email addresses are you actively juggling?
exactly.
email isn't just surviving, it's the backbone of our digital lives. while we're all doom-scrolling on social, our inboxes keep filling up with the stuff that actually matters.
speaking of email dominance, massive shoutout to our beehiiv squad for crushing it and officially hitting $20M ARR :)
turns out turtles and email have something in common â€“ they're both deceptively powerful and here for the long haul.

the best solutions are often the ones nobody sees coming.

sometimes when we are down, all we need is a little push from our friends to get us back on track.
we all experience that initial rush of motivation when starting something new, then suddenly... flatline. the inspiration evaporates and we're stuck upside down, legs flailing.
this is where most people bail, but the successful ones? they push through that dip.
i've been watching this play out in real time with our LinkedIn 50 day posting challenge (hunger games). we're a few weeks in, and for most of the 45 participants, the honeymoon phase is over.
these next few weeks separate the consistent from the quitters.
that's why community matters so much. when motivation fades, having people who flip you right-side up makes all the difference.
sometimes all we need is that little push from someone who sees us struggling.
community, baby. it's the difference between turtle success and turtle failure.
